articles.title: WHO Infant and Young Child Feeding Guidelines

content.headline: Global Standards for Infant Feeding
content.intro: The World Health Organization establishes evidence-based feeding guidelines that support optimal growth, development, and health for infants and young children worldwide. These recommendations form the foundation for healthy feeding practices from birth through early childhood.

sections.title: WHO Key Recommendations
points: Initiate breastfeeding within first hour after birth
Practice exclusive breastfeeding for first 6 months
Continue breastfeeding for 2 years or longer alongside complementary foods
Introduce safe and nutritionally adequate complementary foods at 6 months
Increase food variety, frequency, and consistency as child grows
Practice responsive feeding following child's hunger and satiety cues

sections.title: Benefits of Following WHO Guidelines
sections.content: Adhering to these standards provides significant health advantages:
points: Reduces infant mortality by up to 13% through exclusive breastfeeding
Lowers risk of childhood obesity and chronic diseases later in life
Supports optimal brain development and cognitive function
Strengthens immune system and reduces infection rates
Promotes healthy mother-child bonding and attachment
Provides complete nutrition tailored to infant's developmental needs

sections.title: Implementation Strategies
points: Create supportive environments for breastfeeding mothers
Provide accurate feeding information to parents and caregivers
Train healthcare workers in proper feeding counseling
Develop community support systems for feeding practices
Monitor child growth and feeding patterns regularly
Address feeding challenges with professional guidance
